column2: @PatrickAlphaC 1 slot ‚Äî constant vars are hard coded into the contract‚Äôs byte code at compile time, and immutable vars are hard coded during the execution of the contract‚Äôs constructor.
@SheetFighterNFT Omg üò≠

We managed to bring GPT-3 data on-chain, and store it in an efficient way.

But, that's just the beginning.

@SheetFighterNFT is going to continue to be a hot-bed of creative technicals feats.

Next up?

Our Ethereum <--> Polygon bridge.

Of course, that means we have to parse and split up that long string, when you query the contract for the Sheet's metadata.

But, that's not a problem.

Getting the Sheet's metadata is a view-only transaction, so it costs literally zero gas to parse the string. https://t.co/4EVt2jAFag

Instead of storing each string as a separate variable, we stored them all as one long string, concatenated by a pipe character.

Why would we do that?

To reduce the number of slots the data took up in storage.

Fewer slots = less gas https://t.co/s0kw6zzwBF

After getting the GPT-3 data on-chain, we had to figure out how to store it.

The main challenge was reducing the cost of gas. 

Each sheet had five different pieces of text we had to store, so we did something we hadn't seen done before.

If alarm bells are ringing in your head right now¬†‚Äî good. 

You noticed that anyone could've easily altered "_flavorTexts" and arbitrarily named their Sheets.

That's where the signature came in, which let us verify that "_flavorTexts" was the unaltered text created by GPT-3. https://t.co/I3vYt7BMDf

But, how did the GPT-3 generated texts actually get on-chain?

The answer lies in the smart contact's "mint" function.

When you minted a Sheet, you passed in the GPT-3 generated data yourself. That's the "_flavorTexts" parameter.

This all happened under the hood, of course. https://t.co/uVe88ZIRau

When users (lovingly dubbed "Sheet heads") minted their Sheets, something cool happened.

GPT-3 generated texts that represented their Sheet's name, and the names of it's fighting moves, were placed on-chain. https://t.co/V6NnB4JWTD

The goal of all this was to build something totally new and push the boundaries of what we could do on-chain.

The lore and high production value of the project were huge components of @SheetFighterNFT's success on the day of launch, as were the pretty unique technical nuances.

It's no secret that storing data on Ethereum is expensive ‚Äî brutally expensive. 

But, there was another problem, too.

The GPT-3 generated data had to be created off-chain, and users had to bring it on-chain, themselves. That presented security risks.

So, we had to be creative.

12 days ago, we did something we'd never seen done before.

We took GPT-3 generated data and placed it on-chain on to Ethereum.

Here's how we did it, and why üßµ

Before you consider gas-optimizations that tradeoff security, make sure you've taken care of lower-hanging fruit, like variable ordering.

By grouping smaller datatypes together, StructB uses only two slots.

On the flip side, StructA uses three. https://t.co/c5bVqCWcq9

More slots = more `sstore` operations,

and `sstore` operations are WILDLY expensive.

You can use fewer of them by properly ordering variables.

Why should you care about the order of variables?

The EVM breaks up storage into 32-byte slots.

‚Ä¢ uint8 takes up 1/32 of a slot
‚Ä¢ uint256 takes up an entire slot

But, why does that matter?

StructB stores the same types.

But, there's an obvious twist:

the order. https://t.co/FRYndUJ8hP

StructA stores three numbers.

Two are uint8 types.

One is a uint256 type. https://t.co/J0gpTXKR29

You can easily gas-optimize your Solidity contracts. 

Here's an example: https://t.co/akBZvBq6a2

Most DAO contributors aren't technical.

Most DAO tools suck if you aren't technical.

By approaching Web3 protocols as regular old products, you'll learn all of the valuable context that makes it easier to remember the individual pieces.

Now you don't have to memorize protocol details in isolation.

How is it solving that problem?

In other words, dive deeper into the protocol's implementation, and understand the "how" of what they're doing.

E.g., Chainlink is building a decentralized network of oracles to allow data to enter contracts in a decentralized way.

What problem is it trying to solve?

All protocols are created to solve a problem.

Now that you know the target audience, what is the specific problem they're having?

E.g., prior to Chainlink, Dapp developers were struggling to get real world data into contracts safely.

Who are its users?

Paint a general picture of who the protocol is trying to acquire as a user.

E.g., @chainlink is trying to help developers that are building complex Dapps.

Web3 is an industry. Concepts will stick when you think of Web3 protocols as products in that industry.

The same questions apply:
1. Who are its users?
2. What problem is it trying to solve?
3. How is it solving that problem?
3 steps to learn any complex Web3 protocol:

L2s are facing the same issue as alt L1s:

network effects.

At inception, each L2 has:
‚Ä¢ no liquidity
‚Ä¢ no contracts
‚Ä¢ no users

The problem?

Less utility per user.

In 2017, I was one of the four people I knew writing smart contracts.

In 2022, I'm one of the the ~20 people I know writing smart contracts.

Pick up the skill.

The demand >>> the supply

build.

‚Ä¢ Twitter
‚Ä¢ Discord
‚Ä¢ Telegram

All you need is the willingness to keep trying and keep learning.

The worst understood concept in crypto:

progressive decentralization.

DAOs strive to become decentralized quickly, but it's impossible for any decentralized system to start off that way.

At inception, there needs to be trust that there will quickly not need to be trust.

@josh_blatt_ Rust is definitely fast, but smart contract computation isn't the bottleneck for L1 scalability.

The bottlenecks are:

‚Ä¢ cost of writing data to storage
‚Ä¢ time to consensus for validators

Smart contracts should not be written in general purpose languages, like:
‚Ä¢ Rust
‚Ä¢ JavaScript

Smart contracts should be written in languages built for the task.

The guardrails matter. 

We're operating in a dark forest.
@theyoungcrews The sheer anxiety that would give me

Web3 founders are repeating the painful mistakes Web2 founders made.

Learn from them.

Don't be a product searching for a customer.

Know your customer before you know what you're building.

Fire bullets, before firing cannon balls.

Use prototypes, not products, to verify that you're solving their problem.

quick prototype = tight feedback loop

Most Web3 builders start writing code ASAP, and it prevents them from learning fast. https://t.co/oCkd2QQY56

Don't make the classic Web3 mistake.

Work backwards from your customer:

1. pick your target customer
2. understand their experience
3. solve their most painful problem

A ton of Web3 startups start with a product, and then try to find their customer.

Oof. https://t.co/ZDZVadkWI0

DAOs aren't great, because decision makers aren't necessarily the best informed about a topic, but this is true in traditional orgs, too.
